awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Community-Engaged Student Learning for the Development of Empathy in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Research studies have shown that empathy is an important skill in engineering.  For example, increased empathy can contribute to communication, design processes, professional success, ethics, and the overall culture of engineering. However, development of empathy has not yet been recognized to be an important component of engineering education.  Likely as a result, engineers today generally have less fully developed empathy skills, when compared to professionals in other fields. Community-engaged student learning offers opportunities for engineering students to develop empathy within community-oriented partnerships built around mutual goals. This project will explore community-engaged student learning as a platform inclusion of empathy development in engineering curricula.  Thus, it can provide engineering educators with a mechanism to promote empathy as a key engineering skill.

In this project, the investigators will use quasi-experimental, mixed methods research to:  1) study how community-engaged student learning may foster the development of empathy in engineers; and (2) develop research-informed instructional tools to teach empathy and enhance learning outcomes around empathy in engineering. In the first phase of the project, the goal is to collect baseline data across seven community-engaged learning activities, which include service learning, outreach, and volunteer-type activities within the community. Student reflections, focus groups, and interviews will provide qualitative insight, and quantitative measurements will triangulate findings. The goal of the second phase of the project is to develop instructional tools for empathy.  In the third phase, these instructional tools will be implemented in community-engaged student learning activities and data collection will be repeated to determine the impact of the tools on empathy development in engineering students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research helps engineering educators understand the ways that community-based learning (CBL - i.e., service-learning, outreach, and volunteerism) can support the development of empathy in undergraduate students. We selected six CBL efforts with differing contexts, types of activities, and time commitments to create a broad picture of how CBL can serve as platforms to develop empathy. We collected quantitative data using the Interpersonal Relativity Index (IRI) administered to the students before and after the CBL experience. Qualitative data collection used two approaches, focus groups and interviews, to provide detailed personal accounts of the CBL experiences related to empathy development. Data was collected across two phases of research where in Phase 1, there was no direct instruction of empathy to understand how CBL contexts can naturally promote empathy development. In Phase 2, we taught the participating students about the role empathy plays in engineering and lead them through exercises to foster its development. Our research was built on the established model of empathy in engineering, created by the Co-PI in prior NSF work, to further the ways engineering education can promote empathy in this professional context through CBL.

The key findings (intellectual merit contributions) of this project are as follows: 

  • Community-based learning is shown to promote the development of empathy without any direct instruction, however when empathy is taught, the student gains in this important professional skill are strengthened.
  • Three categories of opportunities exist within engineering CBL pedagogy upon which instructors can meaningfully integrate empathy. Structural opportunities involve ways in which CBL activities are designed to support exposing students to empathy in implicit and explicit ways. Social opportunities include the interactions with others and the ways students approach these interactions. Lastly, interpretative opportunities include the ways instructors can promote approaches through which students can internalize empathy within the CBL experiences to shift perspectives between the “self” and “others”.
  • While these opportunities to integrate empathy within engineering are available to engineering educators, empathy is a complex structure in which its ties to engineering require some time to develop. This research indicated that faculty require support in both understanding the ways empathy is manifested in engineering and ways to effectively include empathy as a learning outcome. This research developed manuscript and supporting documents to enable engineering educators to include empathy in CBL yet further work is needed to facilitate effective adoption.
  • Empathy is a central construct to the positive implementation of CBL ensuring students are learning about appropriate ways to ethically engage with non-engineering collaborators and that community partners are respected, while their needs and assets are centered.

The broad impacts of this project are primarily in the area of improving undergraduate teaching and learning in engineering. Key impacts are as follows: 

  • Empathy within engineering CBL serves as a critical bridge that supports achieving the societal potential of CBL. This research continues an important evolution of CBL practice that positions students as supporters of communities promoting societal change rather than focusing solely on students seeking experiential education.
  • The project has produced knowledge and materials necessary to provide professional development for engineering educators interested in including empathy in CBL. Through this project, six CBL contexts and the 5 faculty who instructed them, were supported with the inclusion of empathy as an explicit learning outcome of their effort. Additionally, two graduate students and two undergraduate students gain substantial experience in educational research methods and manuscript development. One student leveraged this research to complete a doctoral dissertation.        

In summary, this project produced four key findings and associated evidence that can be used to support the inclusion of empathy as a student learning outcome within engineering CBL. Ultimately, this will improve student experiences and engineering formation throughout engineering CBL as well as support the alignment with community needs. This project had significant, positive impact related to growing the extent to which empathy is included within the CBL efforts at the local institution and will continue to be propagated to support further adoption. Additionally, the project provided data and evidence necessary to effect changes and improvements to CBL efforts with a desire to include empathy development.
